My friend and I would get take out: falafel or eggplant sandwiches or shwarma, maybe some potato salad and soup, and walk to the little park just up the block to eat and forget about our work in the sunshine. Pretty great. I just went again yesterday to see if it was still wonderful, and yep, the matzo ball soup was just as I remember, the falafel was great, and I forgot about the plate of pickles - nice touch. Yum!
author: Ali L.

description: really the worst food.  I had serious doubts as I entered the doors looking at the grimy walls and food spattered carpet....I was wanting some authentic middle Eastern cuisine....I'm certain the grease that my food was fried in could have been saved from the time of Moses it was SO old. The smells inside of this stuffy grungy eatery rival a machine shop think essence of crank case oil.  The pastrami was slimy yet dry...how does that happen? The waitstaff was really unfriendly....I felt like the plates were plunked down in front of us with grunting and grimacing....I miss the joy of having food around my Grandmother's table...the fresh cucumbers,tomatoes,home made yogurt....hospitality felt lost at Sabra Grill.  My husband worried about food poisoning....The food was grey looking...grey.
author: Sylvia B.

description: I like the no nonsense attitude. In a city that's getting so far from real, with so many places sporting fake "ambience," I appreciate Sabra's no frills authenticity. I totally love that it's kosher. And I am completely charmed that I have to go to Chinatown to get to an Israeli place.  I'm not a member of the tribe, but I've always been courteously and respectfully treated. The place is clean. I don't get attitude about avoiding meat. The falafel is awesome and so is the hummus. And the pickles. The pickles. The only time I eat all the pickles is when I go to Sabra.
author: Bibi R. R.

description:
We were ending a great day of "food hiking" in SF and had just left a chinese cafe run by a delightful family that served us egg rolls to go when we saw this place. My wife is Jewish and we are always trying to top the falafel we had at a London flea market. The place looked creepy enough on the outside to be really good so we gamely mounted the stairs dragging my two 22ish sons along. We all piled into the plain little room and were glumly surveyed by the Yarmulke clad customers. The owner gave us dirty looks as the young waiter scurried about. The shy son returned to the stairs to avoid the stares. The three of us held our ground until the owner came over to get rid of us. We ordered a falafel to go to everyone's relief. I guess this is a private club. My wife understood the ranting of the owner to the waiter and felt sorry for the waiter. We made it back out to the street with our falafel and rated it about a 6 out of 10- kinda mushy, not a crispy enough shell on the balls. 
Funny though, this is one of the things we will remember and laugh about the most when we recall this trip to SF.
author: Rose C.

description: I had to physically make this post!! What the hell is wrong with the citizens in this orb of numerous sustenance undertakings? This hidden Jerusalem den of delectable delights sits stoic and outside the usual fare right at the tail end of china town. So, anyone would figure, " you order hummus when you're at the corner of pine and grant.....sounds like you were harnessing a surly temperament." Well, there you are: muerte incorrect. I could have been eating chancre sore laced hunan fried rice, or this lovely, impeccable falafel. It was the best falafel ive eaten in quite sometime. the pita was scorching, a marvelous additive along with dense, luscious, feathery, decadent hummus and, you guessed it, pickles without prompting. BAAAAAMM! that corpulent co-opted ass flounder Emeril would have been tres enthusiastic. A gorgeous, notable experience. Its kosher baby, so watch your trousers.
author: Christopher J.

description: I pretty much just need to reiterate what Christopher is saying below. This place is way-overlooked. Probably the most unique dining experience I have had in San Francisco, with all the pious Jewish families with very young children in the small dining room (man, do my people know how to breed). And the pita bread. OMG the pita bread. If only they had pita like this where I grew up.
author: Brett L.

description: 5 stars for a fucking excellent falafel plate, delightfully surly staff, and the pure delight of a kosher restaurant in chinatown.
author: Olivia G.

description: Perhaps the worst shawarma, customer service I have ever had. The owner is very unprofessional and very mean.
author: Tufan A.

description: The Service here is horrible. The guy that answers the phone is the biggest A hole I've ever talked to. I tried ordering a catering buffet with some allergies specifics and the guy answering the phone was so incompetent he got frustrated and hung up. Too bad my order was already placed or I would have used another restaurant. I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone!!! And being in the industry I am already letting everyone know what a dirty dive this is. WE have a lot of guests that need Kosher meals but will never use this dump again!
author: Kelly M.

description: I love the look on the cashiers face when I came upstairs to this little hole in the wall joint with my goy of a boyfriend.  Like he was watching a gorilla and a kitten prance around as lovers.  5 stars for that.  Two stars off for being a little expensive for falafel.  Those things should cost 3 shekels maximum.
author: Tamar N.

description: Only Glatt Kosher option for dinner in San Francisco...maybe there will be more options one day. Sabras serves basic Israeli food, most of which is fine.  They usually only have one waiter serving, so if you go when there are more than 4 tables seated, you might have to wait for attention,so order everything you need the first time!
author: Sam A.

description:
Definitely a strange setting, and I'm not sure I'd enjoy having a long meal there, but it's amazing for takeout.

Everything they use is very high quality - the beef, the hummus, the falafel.. everything.  The owner is a strange combination of New York Tough Guy and devout Orthodox Jew, but he knows how to stuff a pita.  I typically get the falafel and have also been blown away by the schwarma and the beef kebab..  ditto the baba ganoush (sp?) and hummus.

Extra points for the sleepy rabbi in the corner.
author: Brad R.

description: So my gf and I stopped in for a quick bite as we were shopping in the area. We had a chicken shwarma and okay, yes it's a little pricey but cmon it's downtown. And yes, they have a $10 minimum if you want to use a credit card but most items are around that much anyway. But the shwarma was excellent and let me tell you, I'm a very picky shwarma eater. They used fresh veggies, humus was excellent inside, the hot sauce was good and the chicken was cooked well. I'd def want to go back and try some of their other items.....not sure why everyone on here is hating on them so much. And the service, wasn't the greatest but wasn't bad either. The dude was just a little soft spoken and the service was top notch considering its a small tiny spot upstairs in Chinatown.
author: pankaj l.

description: thats the only kosher restaurant i know in san francisco and its great!! good shishlik and very good falafel and humus!!! i still havnt tried all the dishes but i will surtenly will
author: dor w.
